items.synopsis: Two people have been killed and a male offender is dead after a serious incident unfolded at a construction site in Auckland's CBD this morning.

items.synopsis: New Zealand police say a shooting which has left three people dead in World Cup host city Auckland is an isolated incident. Follow live.

title.children: Auckland shooting on eve of World Cup 'not a national security risk'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier we brought you a recount from a witness who ran from the scene on her morning commute. Here's the full interview with Erin Sokolowsky on News Breakfast.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian woman recalls hearing 'scary' gunshots on commute

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Minister for Sport Grant Robertson says he spoke with the President and Secretary-General of FIFA this morning. The Women's World Cup tournament will go ahead and tonight's game at Eden Park stadium in Auckland will be played. "There are a number of teams, as you will be aware, who were staying in the immediate area," Mr Robertson said. "They are all safe and sound and as the cordon moves in, they will go about the normal business of today for them."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: World Cup game will go ahead this evening

children.content: Minister for Sport Grant Robertson says he spoke with the President and Secretary-General of FIFA this morning.
The Women's World Cup tournament will go ahead and tonight's game at Eden Park stadium in Auckland will be played.
"There are a number of teams, as you will be aware, who were staying in the immediate area," Mr Robertson said.
"They are all safe and sound and as the cordon moves in, they will go about the normal business of today for them."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Chris Hipkins says there is no identified political or ideological motivation for the shooting and therefore no national security risk. "I don't have information on what the actual motivation was, other than that the police have not identified any ideological or political motivation for this," he said. "When they are in a position to share more information, I am sure they will do that."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Attack was not politically or ideologically motivated, says prime minister

children.content: Chris Hipkins says there is no identified political or ideological motivation for the shooting and therefore no national security risk.
"I don't have information on what the actual motivation was, other than that the police have not identified any ideological or political motivation for this," he said.
"When they are in a position to share more information, I am sure they will do that."

image.altText: Composite image of Daniel Andrews and Kereyn Smith.

items.synopsis: Commonwealth Games Federation vice-president Kereyn Smith questions Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews's integrity over his decision to axe the 2026 Games.

title.children: 'Unprecedented': Games VP challenges Daniel Andrews's version of events on cancellation

image.altText: The Olympic rings pictured in front of the IOC headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland.

items.synopsis: Victoria hardly had to beat rival contenders for the now-dumped 2026 Commonwealth Games, a far cry from the prize fight bidding war for the coveted Olympics. It begs the question — which event is preferable to host?

title.children: Are the Commonwealth Games really so hard to host?

image.altText: A close up shot of Daniel Andrews face during a media conference.

items.synopsis: Given the scepticism over the new Commonwealth Games costings and the outcry from athletes and regional communities, the pressure to release the analysis the Victorian premier is relying on will only build, writes David Speers.

title.children: The $6 billion canary in a cost-of-living crisis: The mystery blowout that sank the Commonwealth Games

image.altText: Marnus Labuschagne holds the bridge of his nose in frustration while walking off the field

items.synopsis: Predicted rain means this critical fourth Ashes Test could be compressed into three days' worth of play, only adding to the frustration of Australia's batting performance on day one.

title.children: Australia can't close the door on England as Ashes remain alive in Test forced into fast-forward

image.altText: A middle-aged white woman with short grey hair. She is standing by a door, wearing a blue sweater

items.synopsis: Jenny Moncur's husband Royce died in 2014 after being diagnosed with cancer. Almost a decade later, she was still being contacted about his Telstra account.

title.children: 'Like a Monty Python skit': Telstra 'harassed' Jenny for nine years over her dead husband's account

image.altText: Simon Flagg standing in front of a river.

items.synopsis: So far, only two of Victoria's 11 registered Traditional Owner groups are advocating for a Yes vote in the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: Simon's family fought for Aboriginal rights in the 1967 referendum. Now he says it's his turn

image.altText: Horses grazing in a field.

items.synopsis: Progress on developing a national horse traceability system remains months away, as more than a dozen horses die shortly after falling ill in Victoria.

title.children: Mysterious horse death toll rises to 13 as date for a national traceability system remains uncertain

image.altText: An elderly woman in a church

items.synopsis: NSW Police allege in court documents Senior Constable Kristian White's decision to deploy his taser on the elderly woman "does not meet the threshold" of acceptable use for officers.

title.children: Officer said 'na bugger it' before tasering 95yo Clare Nowland, court documents allege

image.altText: Large flatscreen monitors show the top 10 S&P/ASX200 losses

items.synopsis: UK inflation falls by more than expected in June, latest unemployment rate for Australia out this morning.

title.children: UK inflation falls by more than expected, Australia's unemployment rate out this morning

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASX 200 (Wednesday close) : +0.6% to 7,324 points Australian dollar : -0.06% to 67.72 US cents Dow Jones : +0.3% at 35,061 points S & P 500 : +0.2% to 4,565 points Nasdaq Composite : +0.03% to 14,358 points FTSE : +1.8% to 7,588 points STOXX Europe 600 : +0.08% to 3,948 points Spot gold : -1.4% to $US1,977/ounce Brent crude : -0.08% to $US79.55/barrel Bitcoin : -0.1% to $US29,933
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot at 7.50am AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, The Bank of England will be happy with the latest inflation data released in the UK overnight, showing the annual pace of inflation fell to 7.9 per cent in June, down from 8.7 per cent in May. When Reuters polled economists ahead of the data release, the majority view was that the annual pace of inflation was going to decline by a smaller amount, to be running at 8.2 per cent. Core inflation also fell a little, registering 6.9 per cent, down from 7.1 per cent in May (a 31-year high). It means market participants now think the BoE's next rate hike will probably be smaller than expected. They had been expecting a rate hike of 0.5 percentage points in August, but now they think it will be 0.25. In Australia, we'll get new unemployment figures today. The unemployment rate in May was 3.6 per cent, having edged lower from 3.7 per cent in April. Today's number will show what happened in June. In trend terms, the unemployment rate has been sitting at 3.5 per cent for the last 10 months. The Reserve Bank expects the rate to lift to 4.5 per cent by the end of next year as the full effects of its rate hikes work their way through the economy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX expected to open flat, UK inflation falls by more than expected

image.altText: A glowing sign with the letters AI at a conference.

items.synopsis: Internet users are bypassing China's great firewall to connect with a US-made chatbot, as Beijing releases rules paving the way for the country's generative AI boom.

title.children: 'Magic': Tutorials show people in China how to evade censors and connect to ChatGPT

image.altText: Man holding an AFL ball in his hand.

items.synopsis: A coronial inquest hears AFL player Shane Tuck, who had chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), displayed obsessive behaviours and heard voices before his death.

title.children: Former AFL player Shane Tuck's mental health was declining 14 years before his death, coronial inquest hears

image.altText: Lucas Beattie is among the youngest patients to receive gene therapy for Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

items.synopsis: There's no known cure for the genetic condition Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy but a world-first treatment trial is being hailed as a potential "game changer" for children like Lucas.

title.children: Lucas was facing life in a wheelchair until a medical trial gave his parents hope

image.altText: an indigenous man standing next to a large canvas

items.synopsis: An indigenous artist and elder is "disgusted" that a painting he composed of Uluru has been reappropriated to help spread misinformation about the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: What we learnt trying to trace thousands of 'Vote No' flyers being posted across the country

image.altText: Two dingoes on the beach at Fraser Island, with one wearing a GPS tracking collar.

items.synopsis: One of the dingoes involved in the attack of a young woman on K'gari earlier this week has been destroyed. The animal was also responsible for the hospitalisation of a six-year-old girl in April.

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

image.altText: An aerial view of several large buildings and some car parks, with one building highlighted in red.

image.altText: Thai police in dark uniforms stand in lines blocking a road, with large buildings nearby.

image.altText: Soldiers tend a stationary cannon underneath camouflage netting.

title.children: 'It's a meat grinder': Aussie whistleblower claims some Ukrainian Legion commanders are putting soldiers in danger

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin's face is illuminated by a streetlight as he partially smiles through the window of a car, rolled down

items.synopsis: Mr Prigozhin's mutiny, which posed the most serious threat to President Vladimir Putin's 23-year rule, was billed by the mercenary chief as being aimed at ousting Russia's top military leaders whom he accused of incompetence.

image.altText: Athletes are seen before the start of the closing ceremony of the XXI Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast.

items.synopsis: North Korea has stayed silent about the highly unusual entry of an American soldier across the heavily fortified border with South Korea. This is what we know so far and what has happened in the past.

title.children: What we know about the US soldier who 'willfully' crossed the border to North Korea
